title: Nam Theun 2 Hydropower Dam
summary: The $1.45 billion Nam Theun 2 hydropower dam in Laos was the World Bank's flagship development project of the 2000s, generating 1,070 MW primarily for export to Thailand. It required resettling 6,200 people and promised that revenues would fund poverty reduction, but outcomes for resettled communities and downstream populations have been contested.
content:
## Background

Laos, a landlocked, mountainous country in mainland Southeast Asia, has pursued a strategy of becoming the "battery of Southeast Asia" by exploiting its considerable hydropower potential to generate electricity for export to neighboring countries, particularly Thailand. With over 60 planned or operating hydropower projects, the sector is central to the government's development strategy and represents the country's largest source of foreign exchange and government revenue.

Nam Theun 2 (NT2), located in Khammouane Province in central Laos, was the most significant and scrutinized of these projects. First proposed in the early 1990s, the project underwent over a decade of planning, environmental and social assessment, and international debate before reaching financial close in 2005. The World Bank's decision to provide guarantees and financing was intensely contested, with the project becoming a test case for whether large dams could be built responsibly in developing countries.

The project was developed by the Nam Theun 2 Power Company (NTPC), a consortium led by Electricité de France (EDF) with the Lao government holding 25%, EGCO (Thailand) 25%, and Ital-Thai Development 12.5%. The dam creates a reservoir on the Nakai Plateau by damming the Nam Theun River, then diverts water through a tunnel to a powerhouse on the Xe Bang Fai River, generating 1,070 MW of power. Approximately 95% of the electricity is sold to Thailand's Electricity Generating Authority (EGAT) under a 25-year power purchase agreement.

## The Intervention

The World Bank's involvement was predicated on an unprecedented set of conditions designed to ensure that revenues would benefit the Lao poor and that environmental and social impacts would be mitigated. The framework included: a Revenue Management Arrangement directing government revenues from NT2 toward priority poverty reduction programs in health, education, infrastructure, and environmental management; a comprehensive Environmental Assessment and Management Plan (EAMP); and a Social Development Plan for the 6,200 people resettled from the Nakai Plateau.

Resettled communities were provided with new housing, agricultural land, access to reservoir fisheries, community forestry areas, and livelihood programs intended to restore and improve their incomes within five years. An additional 120,000 people downstream on the Xe Bang Fai River, whose fisheries and riverside agriculture would be affected by changed water flows, were included in a Downstream Program providing compensation and livelihood support.

Porter and Shivakumar (2011), in the World Bank's own assessment, documented the elaborate safeguard framework, noting that NT2 set new standards for environmental and social preparation in hydropower development. An independent Panel of Experts and an International Advisory Group provided ongoing oversight, and the project maintained extensive monitoring programs for environmental and social outcomes.

## Results & Evidence

The dam was completed on time and began commercial operation in March 2010. It has generally performed well technically, generating revenues of approximately $80–100 million annually for the Lao government. The concession will revert to the Lao government in 2035, after which all revenues will accrue domestically. Total government revenues over the concession period are estimated at approximately $2 billion.

However, outcomes for affected communities have been more problematic. The International Rivers organization and independent researchers documented that resettled communities on the Nakai Plateau struggled to achieve livelihood restoration targets. Agricultural productivity on the new land was lower than anticipated, reservoir fisheries were less productive than projected, and the promised community forestry programs faced implementation challenges. A 2015 World Bank review acknowledged that household incomes for resettled communities had not reached pre-project levels, though improvements in housing, water supply, and access to services were noted.

Downstream impacts on the Xe Bang Fai were significant. The diversion of water from the Nam Theun to the Xe Bang Fai altered the river's hydrology, increasing dry-season flows, changing flood patterns, and reducing water quality. Downstream communities reported declining fish catches, damage to riverside vegetable gardens, and erosion of riverbanks. While the Downstream Program provided some compensation, affected communities described the mitigation as inadequate relative to the losses experienced.

## Challenges & Criticisms

The revenue management framework—the mechanism intended to ensure that dam revenues translated into poverty reduction—has been difficult to evaluate. While revenues were channeled into government budget lines designated for poverty reduction, the extent to which this represented additional spending (above what would have occurred anyway) versus fungibility (relabeling existing spending) is contested. Laos remains a one-party state with limited budget transparency, and independent monitoring of revenue utilization has been constrained by the political environment.

Critics, including International Rivers and the Environmental Defense Fund, argued that the NT2 model was used to legitimize a broader dam-building program in Laos that proceeded without equivalent safeguards. Projects like the Xayaburi Dam on the Mekong mainstream and the collapsed Xe Pian-Xe Namnoy Dam (2018, which killed at least 71 people and displaced 6,000) demonstrated that NT2's safeguard standards were the exception rather than the rule. The concern is that the World Bank's endorsement of NT2 provided political cover for a dam-building agenda whose overall environmental and social record is poor.

## Key Lessons

- Even with extensive safeguards, large dam projects struggle to achieve livelihood restoration for resettled communities, particularly when livelihood programs depend on assumptions about agricultural productivity and fisheries that prove overly optimistic.
- Revenue management frameworks require genuine budget transparency and independent monitoring to ensure that resource revenues translate into additional poverty reduction spending rather than substituting for existing allocations.
- Flagship projects with exceptional safeguards may legitimize broader programs that operate with far lower standards, creating a "halo effect" that obscures cumulative impacts.
- Downstream impacts of water diversion are difficult to fully mitigate and may be underestimated in project planning, particularly effects on fisheries and riverine livelihoods.
- The 25-year concession model means that full development benefits depend on the host government's capacity to manage the asset after transfer, highlighting the importance of institutional development alongside infrastructure investment.
